security_audit.summary: No data theft, malicious execution, or obfuscation patterns were found. The files contain documentation and examples focused on Seaborn plotting usage.

content.value_statement: Struggling to choose the right statistical plot for your data. This skill guides Seaborn choices, parameters, and layouts for clear, publication-ready figures.
actual_capabilities: Recommend Seaborn plot types for distributions, relationships, and categories
Explain axes-level versus figure-level functions and when to use each
Suggest semantic mappings using hue, size, and style encodings
Provide guidance for faceting with FacetGrid, PairGrid, and JointGrid
Outline theme, palette, and context settings for publication figures
limitations: Requires a Python environment with seaborn and matplotlib to run code
Cannot render or display figures directly in this skill
Does not create interactive dashboards or web visualizations
Needs user-provided data or column names to tailor plots

use_cases.title: Explore relationships quickly
use_cases.description: Pick the best Seaborn plots to examine correlations, trends, and distributions in a new dataset.

use_cases.title: Build publication figures
use_cases.description: Apply themes, palettes, and multi-panel layouts for publication-ready statistical graphics.

use_cases.title: Learn plot selection
use_cases.description: Get guidance on which Seaborn functions match common variable types and analysis goals.

prompt_templates.title: Choose a plot type
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner deciding how to visualize two variables
prompt_templates.prompt: I have columns total_bill and tip with a category day. Which Seaborn plot should I use and why?

prompt_templates.title: Add semantic mappings
prompt_templates.prompt: Suggest how to encode time as hue and size in a scatterplot using Seaborn, and explain key parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Facet a dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to facet by sex and time for a relational plot, and explain figure-level settings.

prompt_templates.title: Polish for publication
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend Seaborn theme, palette, and context settings for a publication figure, with rationale.

output_examples.input: I want to compare distributions across categories and highlight subgroups.
output: Use a violin plot or box plot to compare category distributions
Add a strip or swarm layer to show individual points
Map subgroup to hue and set dodge for side-by-side comparison
Choose a colorblind-safe palette for clarity

best_practices: Use long-form data for flexible variable mapping and faceting
Match plot type to variable types and analysis goal
Set theme and context early for consistent styling
anti_patterns: Using wide-form data for complex multi-variable plots
Overloading one plot with too many semantic mappings
Relying on default binning without checking distribution shape

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides Seaborn guidance that works across these platforms.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It does not run code or render plots. It provides guidance and examples only.

faq.question: Can I integrate the guidance into my notebook workflow?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the suggestions directly in Python notebooks with seaborn and matplotlib.

faq.question: Does this skill access my data or files?
faq.answer: No. It only uses the details you provide in your prompt.

faq.question: What if my plot looks cluttered or unreadable?
faq.answer: Reduce mappings, use faceting, or adjust themes and palettes for clarity.

faq.question: How does this compare to general plotting help?
faq.answer: It is focused on Seaborn-specific functions, parameters, and statistical plotting patterns.
